column1: The library of the University of Louvain possessed 500 manuscripts
column5: 000 volumes. One noted especially the original of the bull of foundation of the university in 1425
column6: an example on vellum of the famous work of André Vésale
column8: an example given to the university by Charles V.
column9: a precious manuscript by Thomas à Kempis. The bibliographical curiosities were numerous; the collection of old Flemish bindings of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries contained some curious specimens. The souvenirs of the ancient university
column14: were preciously guarded in cases. The old printed matters of the sixteenth century formed an extremely rare treasury; all the pieces
column16: and placards on the reform of the Low Countries were kept together in a "varia" volume
column17: thus constituting a unique ensemble. It was the same with a host of pieces relating to Jansenism.
